Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a Liquid Chromatograph-High Resolution Mass Spectrometer to Characterize Organic Molecules of Environmental and Health Significance

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Naturally occurring and synthetic organic molecules play multifaceted roles in the ecosystem and human health. Comprehensive characterization of these organic molecules help advance our scientific understanding of various environmental and health challenges that impact society. This project supports the acquisition of a state-of-the-art liquid chromatograph-high resolution mass spectrometer (LC-HRMS) at Syracuse University (SU). This instrument will enhance research and training on the measurement of organic molecules in diverse samples and enable SU investigators and researchers in central New York to tackle multidisciplinary research questions at the interface of environment and health. This instrument will also strengthen SU’s curriculum and research training programs and broaden participation of students from underrepresented groups in scientific inquiries to foster diversity and inclusion in collaborative research and creative work at SU.

Acquisition of a liquid chromatograph-high resolution mass spectrometer (LC-HRMS) will bring to Syracuse University (SU) a next-generation analytical tool to support a broad array of mass spectrometry applications ranging from contaminant screening and molecular fingerprinting to structural and quantitative proteomics. This instrument will fill a crucial gap in organic analytical facilities at SU and accelerate the pace of many ongoing and planned research projects in priority areas of national interest, such as water quality and treatment, biogeochemistry, indoor environmental quality, chemical biology, and bioinspired materials. This instrument will present new opportunities for SU faculty and students to develop novel screening and discovery workflows and to engage in new interdisciplinary collaborations with researchers spanning multiple disciplines and multiple institutions from central New York and beyond. This instrument will also expose SU students to cutting-edge mass spectrometry methods via new active-learning course modules and research training programs and equip them with analytical skills and scientific thinking needed to further their education. The long-term vision for operating this instrument as a shared user facility is to pursue leading-edge research and enhance SU’s core education mission by providing new analytical capabilities and technical expertise to SU and regional communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This MRI project funded the acquisition of a state-of-the-art liquid chromatography-high-resolution mass spectrometry system for Syracuse University. The high-resolution mass spectrometer is hyphenated with an ultra-high-performance liquid chromatograph (preceded by a robotic liquid handling system) and a nano-flow high-performance liquid chromatograph. Installed and commissioned in May 2022, the system is currently housed in one of the Environmental Engineering laboratories on campus as a shared user facility and alternates between small molecule and proteomics modes monthly to meet the analytical needs of various user groups. The instrument serves as a powerful analytical platform for in-depth screening, quantitative analysis, and structural elucidation of small and large organic molecules of environmental and health significance. The instrument represents a critically needed addition to Syracuse University’s existing instrumentation capacity and has propelled research in areas of societal importance. The PIs and their research groups have utilized the instrument to develop new target and nontarget screening methods for the characterization of organic contaminants in environmental samples as well as targeted and label-free quantitative analysis methods to support proteomics research. To date, projects that have leveraged the new capabilities afforded by the instrument primarily include the identification of unknown N-nitrosamines, wastewater surveillance for substance use assessment, and organic micropollutant screening. The work supported by the instrument has led to peer-review articles published or submitted as well as national conference presentations. The instrument enhances research training and experiential learning opportunities for students at Syracuse and promotes the participation of underrepresented groups in science and engineering. Multiple graduate and undergraduate students from Environmental Engineering and Chemistry programs have benefited from hands-on experience with the instrument and acquire the analytical skills needed to advance their education and career. As the user base continues to expand, the instrument will engage more investigators and students, both from Syracuse and the broader community, in developing new collaborative research and creative work. Overall, this instrument is anticipated to support research and research training on mass spectrometry applications at Syracuse University for the years to come.
